author: Roberto Bolaño
description: Bolaño’s sprawling posthumous epic spans continents, literary obsessions, and a haunting series of crimes in the desert city of Santa Teresa.

title: Gravity and Grace
author: Simone Weil
description: A collection of Weil’s notebooks reflecting on attention, suffering, and spirituality—dense but illuminating philosophical fragments.

title: Man and His Symbols
author: Carl G. Jung
description: Jung’s accessible introduction to analytical psychology, symbolism, and the language of dreams, compiled with his closest collaborators.

title: Crime and Punishment
author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
description: Dostoevsky’s psychological masterpiece follows Raskolnikov’s inner turmoil after committing murder in St. Petersburg.

title: The Myth of Sisyphus
author: Albert Camus
description: Camus meditates on the absurd, rebellion, and what it means to live without appeal in a seemingly meaningless universe.

title: Frankenstein
author: Mary Shelley
description: Mary Shelley’s Gothic novel follows Victor Frankenstein, a young scientist who creates a living being only to face the devastating moral, emotional, and societal consequences of playing God.

title: The Brothers Karamazov
author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
description: Dostoevsky’s philosophical novel explores faith, doubt, morality, and free will through the turbulent relationships of the Karamazov family, culminating in a dramatic murder trial that questions justice and human responsibility.

title: East of Eden
author: John Steinbeck
description: Steinbeck’s epic novel traces the intertwined histories of the Trask and Hamilton families in California, exploring themes of good and evil, freedom of choice, and the idea that humans can overcome their own flawed nature.

title: Moby-Dick
author: Herman Melville
description: Melville’s novel follows Ishmael and the obsessive Captain Ahab on a perilous voyage to hunt the white whale Moby Dick, exploring themes of obsession, fate, humanity, and the power of nature.
